qas.question: What was the main city of Tokharistan?
What was the central part of Transoxiana called?
In what year did the Day of Thirst occur?
Who was the leader of the revolt of 734?
Who suffered worse defeats in the west?
What area was easy to govern?
What was the Umayyad victory in 724 called?
What governor stuck to his promise of tax relief to the Sogdians?
Who was able to capture Merv?

context: <b5_0>Hisham<b5_0/> suffered still worse defeats in the east, where his armies attempted to subdue both <b6_0>Tokharistan<b6_0/>, with its center at <a0_0>Balkh<a0_0/>, and Transoxiana, with its center at <a1_0>Samarkand<a1_0/>. Both areas had already been partially conquered, but remained difficult to govern. Once again, a particular difficulty concerned the question of the conversion of non-Arabs, especially the Sogdians of Transoxiana. Following the Umayyad defeat in the "<b7_0>Day of Thirst<b7_0/>" in <a2_0>724<a2_0/>, <b8_0>Ashras ibn 'Abd Allah al-Sulami<b8_0/>, governor of Khurasan, promised tax relief to those Sogdians who converted to Islam, but went back on his offer when it proved too popular and threatened to reduce tax revenues. Discontent among the Khurasani Arabs rose sharply after the losses suffered in the <a3_0>Battle of the Defile<a3_0/> in 731, and in 734, <a4_0><b9_0>al-Harith ibn Surayj<b9_0/><a4_0/> led a revolt that received broad backing from Arabs and natives alike, capturing Balkh but failing to take Merv. After this defeat, al-Harith's movement seems to have been dissolved, but the problem of the rights of non-Arab Muslims would continue to plague the Umayyads.
